Yes, it's not easy to see how maple leaves or deer antlers are "swift as wind, fierce as fire, immovable as mountain," or Takeda or Uesugi related.   

Come to think of it, Milt, you were the underbidder on that very tsuba.  Haynes [sale 5: item 63] illustrates a virtually identical tsuba, differing slightly in dimensions (Haynes' is a little smaller). Also Haynes' maple leaves have gold nunome highlights, while my tsuba retains traces of red pigment.  I called mine Shoami, and described it as mid-to late Edo, while Haynes identifies his as Kyo Shoami, and attributes it specifically to Genroku.  

If you'd like to compare them. mine is at:

http://www.zincavage.org/DeerandMaple.html

I'll soon be adding the Haynes picture for comparison, and modifying the text.  


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: MuramasaIII@... 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Wednesday, April 13, 2005 9:28 AM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Takeda Shingen & Uetsugi Kenshin symbolism



  In a message dated 4/13/2005 11:01:25 A.M. Central Daylight Time,  
  jdz@... writes:

  when I  finally obtained a copy of the 5th Haynes Auction Catalogue from the  
  1980s.  Mr. Haynes listed an almost identical tsuba, I would say clearly  
  from the same hand, stating that these were symbols of the battles between  
  Takeda Shingen and Uesugi Kenshin.  So I was trying to pursue that lead.  




  I fail to see the connection but then Haynes is Haynes..........
  if there's an " animal connection ", then it should be a tree and a bird (  
  woodpecker ? ). Recall that battle when the Takada  diverted part of the  army 
  to sneak attack the castle where Uesugi was holding up ? Except when they  
  arrived, the Uesugi already left in the fog, crossed the river and attack the  
  Takada base camp. Same battle as Shingen blocked Kenshin's sword with his war  
  fan.

  milt
